metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Array Search
Array Find and Search Methods

content.html:
Array indexOf()
Array lastIndexOf()
Array includes()


See Also:

Basic Methods
Sort Methods
Iteration Methods 		Array find()
Array findIndex()
Array findLast()
Array findLastIndex()

content.text: JavaScript Array indexOf()
The indexOf() method searches an array for an element value and returns its position.
content.html: The indexOf() method searches an array for an element value and returns its position.

content.text: Note: The first item has position 0, the second item has position 1, and so on.
content.html: Note: The first item has position 0, the second item has position 1, and so on.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let position = fruits.indexOf("Apple") + 1;

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html:
item Required. The item to search for.
start Optional. Where to start the search. Negative values will start at the given position counting from the end, and search to the end.

content.text: Array.indexOf() returns -1 if the item is not found.
content.html: Array.indexOf() returns -1 if the item is not found.

content.text: If the item is present more than once, it returns the position of the first occurrence.
content.html: If the item is present more than once, it returns the position of the first occurrence.

content.text: JavaScript Array lastIndexOf()
Array.lastIndexOf() is the same as Array.indexOf() , but returns the position of the last occurrence of the specified element.
content.html: Array.lastIndexOf() is the same as Array.indexOf(), but returns the position of the last occurrence of the specified element.

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let position = fruits.lastIndexOf("Apple") + 1;

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html:
item Required. The item to search for
start Optional. Where to start the search. Negative values will start at the given position counting from the end, and search to the beginning

content.text: JavaScript Array includes()
ECMAScript 2016 introduced Array.includes() to arrays. This allows us to check if an element is present in an array (including NaN, unlike indexOf).
content.html: ECMAScript 2016 introduced Array.includes() to arrays. This allows us to check if an element is present in an array (including NaN, unlike indexOf).

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];

fruits.includes("Mango"); // is true

content.text: Syntax
Array.includes() allows to check for NaN values. Unlike Array.indexOf().
content.html: Array.includes() allows to check for NaN values. Unlike Array.indexOf().

content.text: Browser Support
includes() is an ECMAScript 2016 feature.
content.html: includes() is an ECMAScript 2016 feature.

content.text: ES 2016 is fully supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:
content.html: ES 2016 is fully supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 52 Edge 15 Firefox 52 Safari 10.1 Opera 39
Jul 2016 Apr 2017 Mar 2017 May 2017 Aug 2016

content.text: includes() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: includes() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: JavaScript Array find()
The find() method returns the value of the first array element that passes a test function.
content.html: The find() method returns the value of the first array element that passes a test function.

content.text: This example finds (returns the value of) the first element that is larger than 18:
content.html: This example finds (returns the value of) the first element that is larger than 18:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [4, 9, 16, 25, 29];
let first = numbers.find(myFunction);

function myFunction(value, index, array) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:

content.text: Browser Support
find() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).
content.html: find() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).

content.text: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:
content.html: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 51 Edge 15 Firefox 54 Safari 10 Opera 38
May 2016 Apr 2017 Jun 2017 Sep 2016 Jun 2016

content.text: find() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: find() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: JavaScript Array findIndex()
The findIndex() method returns the index of the first array element that passes a test function.
content.html: The findIndex() method returns the index of the first array element that passes a test function.

content.text: This example finds the index of the first element that is larger than 18:
content.html: This example finds the index of the first element that is larger than 18:

content.code_html:
const numbers = [4, 9, 16, 25, 29];
let first = numbers.findIndex(myFunction);

function myFunction(value, index, array) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:
content.html: Note that the function takes 3 arguments:

content.text: Browser Support
findIndex() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).
content.html: findIndex() is an ES6 feature (JavaScript 2015).

content.text: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:
content.html: ES6 is fully supported in all modern browsers since June 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 51 Edge 15 Firefox 54 Safari 10 Opera 38
May 2016 Apr 2017 Jun 2017 Sep 2016 Jun 2016

content.text: findIndex() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: findIndex() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: JavaScript Array findLast() Method
ES2023 added the findLast() method that will start from the end of an array and return the value of the first element that satisfies a condition.
content.html: ES2023 added the findLast() method that will start from the end of an array and return the value of the first element that satisfies a condition.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let high = temp.findLast(x => x > 40);

content.code:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let high = temp.findLast(x => x > 40);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let high = temp.findLast(x => x > 40);

content.code_html:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let high = temp.findLast(x => x > 40);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let high = temp.findLast(x => x > 40);

content.text: Browser Support
findLast() is an ES2023 feature.
content.html: findLast() is an ES2023 feature.

content.text: It is supported in all modern browsers since July 2023:
content.html: It is supported in all modern browsers since July 2023:

content.code_html:
Chrome 110 Edge 110 Firefox 115 Safari 16.4 Opera 96
Feb 2023 Feb 2023 Jul 2023 Mar 2023 May 2023

content.text: JavaScript Array findLastIndex() Method
The findLastIndex() method finds the index of the last element that satisfies a condition.
content.html: The findLastIndex() method finds the index of the last element that satisfies a condition.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let pos = temp.findLastIndex(x => x > 40);

content.code:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let pos = temp.findLastIndex(x => x > 40);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let pos = temp.findLastIndex(x => x > 40);

content.code_html:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let pos = temp.findLastIndex(x => x > 40);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const temp = [27, 28, 30, 40, 42, 35, 30];
let pos = temp.findLastIndex(x => x > 40);

content.text: Browser Support
findLastIndex() is an ES2023 feature.
content.html: findLastIndex() is an ES2023 feature.

content.text: It is supported in all modern browsers since July 2023:
content.html: It is supported in all modern browsers since July 2023:

content.code_html:
Chrome 110 Edge 110 Firefox 115 Safari 16.4 Opera 96
Feb 2023 Feb 2023 Jul 2023 Mar 2023 May 2023

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: const fruits = ['Apple', 'Orange', 'Mango']; let x = fruits.indexOf('Orange'); What will the result of x ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
const fruits = ['Apple', 'Orange', 'Mango'];
let x = fruits.indexOf('Orange');
What will the result of x?
